An absence of plumbing in half the homes in one of our own TN counties is not just an embarrassment, it's life and death for the residents. That's why the U.S. stepped up to help them. Our state should not be hoarding the aid.

"The federal government has designated Grundy County 'persistently poor,' with a poverty rate topping 20% since 1990. Among children, the poverty rate is 31%. Half of all homes lack plumbing in the county and 15% of the housing stock is substandard."
"Tennessee receives $191 million each year from the federal government for Families First, with no time limit on how it is spent.”

According to @Tennessean, "The TANF benefits, known as Families First in Tennessee, are intended to provide short-term assistance to families with children who have fallen on hard times, serving as a bridge until parents find jobs or earn a degree."

While Tennessee put more than $730M from the federal govt for Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) in the state's "rainy day fund," it has been pouring buckets on Tennessee families. https://www.tennessean.com/story/news/local/2019/11/25/one-tennessees-poorest-counties-unspent-tanf-funding-stings/4228776002/ …
